Sure, I can convert the HTML code into a React component. Heres the code split into a functional React component:

  1. Install dependencies:

    bash
    npm install @fortawesome/fontawesome-free

  2. Create a new file SignIn.js and add the following code:

jsx
import React from 'react';
import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css';
import './SignIn.css'; // Make sure to create and include the CSS file

const SignIn = () => {
    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="screen">
                <div className="screen__content">
                    <form className="login">
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-user"></i>
                            <input type="text" className="login__input" placeholder="Username" />
                        </div>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-lock"></i>
                            <input type="password" className="login__input" placeholder="Password" />
                        </div>
                        <button className="button login__submit">
                            <span className="button__text">Sign In</span>
                            <i className="button__icon fas fa-chevron-right"></i>
                        </button>
                    </form>
                    <div className="social-login">
                        <h3>New user?</h3>
                        <div className="social-icons">
                            <a href="./signup.html" className="social-login__icon">Sign Up</a>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                    <div className="homepage">
                        <h5><a href="./index.html" style={{ textDecoration: 'none', color: 'darkred' }}>Home Page</a></h5>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <div className="screen__background">
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape4"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape3"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape2"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape1"></span>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
}

export default SignIn;
  1. Create a CSS file SignIn.css and add the following styles:
css

    bottom: 0px;
    right: 0px;

    padding: 20px 10px;

.homepage {

    top: 15px;

    text-align: center;
    color: darkred;
    cursor: pointer;
    text-decoration: none;
}

.homepage:hover {
    transform: scale(1.2);
}

  1. Ensure you have the image login.png in the ./imagini/ directory or update the path to where your image is located.

  2. Import and use the SignIn component in your main application file, e.g., App.js:

jsx
import React from 'react';
import SignIn from './SignIn';

const App = () => {
    return (
        <div>
            <SignIn />
        </div>
    );
}

export default App;

SignIn.js

jsx
import React from 'react';
import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css';
import './SignIn.css';

const SignIn = () => {
    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="screen">
                <div className="screen__content">

                            <input type="password" className="login__input" placeholder="Password" />
                        </div>
                        <button className="button login__submit">
                            <span className="button__text">Sign In</span>
                            <i className="button__icon fas fa-chevron-right"></i>
                        </button>
                    </form>
                    <div className="social-login">
                        <h3>New user?</h3>
                        <div className="social-icons">
                            <a href="./signup.html" className="social-login__icon">Sign Up</a>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                    <div className="homepage">

                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape1"></span>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
}

Make sure you have the image login.png in the correct directory, or update the path in the CSS file to reflect the correct location of your background image.

If you follow these adjustments, the layout should look correct, and the text should be properly aligned. If the issue persists, you might need to further tweak the flexbox properties or inspect the specific elements using your browser's developer tools.

If the text is present but not visible, it could be due to the color of the text being too similar to the background. To ensure the text is visible, let's adjust the color properties in the CSS file.

Updated BenefitsMain Component

Here's your updated BenefitsMain component:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import Navbar from '../Common/Navbar';
import Benefits from './innerComponents/Benefits';
import Footer from '../Common/Footer';
import Sidebar from '../Common/Sidebar';
import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css';
import 'w3-css/w3.css';
import '../../assets/CSS/App.css';
import Header from "../Common/Header.jsx";

function BenefitsMain() {
    const [sidebarOpen, setSidebarOpen] = useState(false);

    const handleSidebarToggle = () => {
        setSidebarOpen(!sidebarOpen);
    };

    const w3_open = () => {
        const mySidebar = document.getElementById('mySidebar');
        if (mySidebar.style.display === 'block') {
            mySidebar.style.display = 'none';
        } else {
            mySidebar.style.display = 'block';
        }
    };

    const w3_close = () => {
        const mySidebar = document.getElementById('mySidebar');
        mySidebar.style.display = 'none';
    };

    return (
        <div className="BenefitsMain">
            <Navbar onSidebarToggle={handleSidebarToggle} />
            <Sidebar isOpen={sidebarOpen} onClose={handleSidebarToggle} />
            <Header />
            <Benefits />
            <Footer />
        </div>
    );
}

export default BenefitsMain;

import React from 'react'; import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css'; import '../../../assets/CSS/SignIn.css'; const SignIn = () => { return ( <div className="container"> <div className="screen"> <div className="screen__content"> <form className="login"> <div className="login__field"> <i className="login__icon fas fa-user"></i> <input type="text" className="login__input" placeholder="Username" /> </div> <div className="login__field"> <i className="login__icon fas fa-lock"></i> <input type="password" className="login__input" placeholder="Password" /> </div> <button className="button login__submit"> <span className="button__text">Sign In</span> <i className="button__icon fas fa-chevron-right"></i> </button> </form> <div className="social-login"> <h3>New user?</h3> <div className="social-icons"> <a href="/signup" className="social-login__icon">Sign Up</a> </div> </div> <div className="homepage"> <h5><a href="/">Home Page</a></h5> </div> </div> <div className="screen__background"> <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape4"></span> <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape3"></span> <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape2"></span> <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape1"></span> </div> </div> </div> ); } export default SignIn; ok so for sign in when it is clicked i want that if the user is ok ( password and username wise ) ( it fetches data from rest api like i have implemented it in java) to show a message like (you are logged in) and oven the Events component. Else show a message that credentials are wrong

To implement the functionality where clicking the "Sign In" button verifies the user's credentials against a REST API and conditionally displays messages or navigates to another component, you need to use React's state management, event handling, and potentially a router for navigation. I'll show you how to achieve this step by step.

Step 1: Setup State and Event Handling in SignIn Component

First, you'll need to set up state to manage the username, password, and the messages that will be displayed based on the login attempt. You will also handle the form submission to call the REST API.

SignIn.js

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { useHistory } from 'react-router-dom'; // Import useHistory for navigation
import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css';
import '../../../assets/CSS/SignIn.css';

const SignIn = () => {
    const [username, setUsername] = useState('');
    const [password, setPassword] = useState('');
    const [message, setMessage] = useState('');
    const history = useHistory(); // useHistory hook for navigation

    const handleLogin = async (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        try {
            const response = await fetch('YOUR_API_ENDPOINT', {
                method: 'POST',
                headers: {
                    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
                },
                body: JSON.stringify({ username, password }),
            });

            if (response.ok) {
                const data = await response.json();
                if (data.success) { // Assuming API returns a success field
                    setMessage('You are logged in');
                    history.push('/events'); // Navigate to Events component
                } else {
                    setMessage('Credentials are wrong');
                }
            } else {
                setMessage('Error logging in');
            }
        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Error:', error);
            setMessage('Error logging in');
        }
    };

    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="screen">
                <div className="screen__content">
                    <form className="login" onSubmit={handleLogin}>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-user"></i>
                            <input
                                type="text"
                                className="login__input"
                                placeholder="Username"
                                value={username}
                                onChange={(e) => setUsername(e.target.value)}
                            />
                        </div>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-lock"></i>
                            <input
                                type="password"
                                className="login__input"
                                placeholder="Password"
                                value={password}
                                onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
                            />
                        </div>
                        <button className="button login__submit" type="submit">
                            <span className="button__text">Sign In</span>
                            <i className="button__icon fas fa-chevron-right"></i>
                        </button>
                    </form>
                    {message && <p>{message}</p>}
                    <div className="social-login">
                        <h3>New user?</h3>
                        <div className="social-icons">
                            <a href="/signup" className="social-login__icon">Sign Up</a>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                    <div className="homepage">
                        <h5><a href="/">Home Page</a></h5>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <div className="screen__background">
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape4"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape3"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape2"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape1"></span>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
};

export default SignIn;

Step 2: Setup Routing

To navigate to the Events component upon successful login, you need to have routing set up in your application. Ensure you have react-router-dom installed.

bash
npm install react-router-dom

App.js

Update your App.js to include the router and define the routes.

jsx
import React from 'react';
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Route, Switch } from 'react-router-dom';
import SignIn from './components/SignIn';
import Events from './components/Events'; // Import your Events component
import './assets/CSS/App.css';

function App() {
    return (
        <Router>
            <div className="App">
                <Switch>
                    <Route path="/" exact component={SignIn} />
                    <Route path="/events" component={Events} />
                    {/* Add other routes here */}
                </Switch>
            </div>
        </Router>
    );
}

export default App;

Summary

With these steps, you set up a SignIn component that:

  • Accepts user input for username and password.
  • Submits the credentials to a REST API.
  • Displays a message based on the API response.
  • Navigates to the Events component upon successful login.

This ensures a smooth user experience for logging in and accessing the events page.

To integrate the authentication functionality using the provided axios API and to navigate to the Events component upon successful login, follow these steps:

Step 1: Update SignIn Component to Use axios for Authentication

  1. Update the SignIn Component to use the signIn function from your API file.
  2. Display messages based on the API response.

SignIn.js

Update your SignIn.js component to use the signIn function.

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { useHistory } from 'react-router-dom';
import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css';
import '../../../assets/CSS/SignIn.css';
import { signIn } from '../../../api'; // Adjust the import path as needed

const SignIn = () => {
    const [username, setUsername] = useState('');
    const [password, setPassword] = useState('');
    const [message, setMessage] = useState('');
    const history = useHistory();

    const handleLogin = async (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        try {
            const response = await signIn({ username, password });
            if (response.success) { // Assuming API returns a success field
                setMessage('You are logged in');
                history.push('/events'); // Navigate to Events component
            } else {
                setMessage('Credentials are wrong');
            }
        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Error:', error);
            setMessage('Error logging in');
        }
    };

    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="screen">
                <div className="screen__content">
                    <form className="login" onSubmit={handleLogin}>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-user"></i>
                            <input
                                type="text"
                                className="login__input"
                                placeholder="Username"
                                value={username}
                                onChange={(e) => setUsername(e.target.value)}
                            />
                        </div>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-lock"></i>
                            <input
                                type="password"
                                className="login__input"
                                placeholder="Password"
                                value={password}
                                onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
                            />
                        </div>
                        <button className="button login__submit" type="submit">
                            <span className="button__text">Sign In</span>
                            <i className="button__icon fas fa-chevron-right"></i>
                        </button>
                    </form>
                    {message && <p>{message}</p>}
                    <div className="social-login">
                        <h3>New user?</h3>
                        <div className="social-icons">
                            <a href="/signup" className="social-login__icon">Sign Up</a>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                    <div className="homepage">
                        <h5><a href="/">Home Page</a></h5>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <div className="screen__background">
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape4"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape3"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape2"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape1"></span>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
};

export default SignIn;

Step 2: Update the API File

Uncomment the signIn function and ensure it correctly points to your authentication endpoint.

api.js

javascript
import axios from 'axios';

const API_URL = 'http://localhost:55555'; // Replace with your actual API URL
const WS_URL = 'ws://your-websocket-url.com'; // Replace with your actual WebSocket URL

// Event APIs
export const getEvents = async () => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.get(`${API_URL}/events`);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error fetching events:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

export const joinEvent = async (eventId) => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.post(`${API_URL}/events/join`, { eventId });
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error joining event:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

// User APIs
export const getUser = async () => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.get(`${API_URL}/user`);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error fetching user:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

export const getCoupons = async () => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.get(`${API_URL}/coupons`);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error fetching coupons:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

export const getMedicalInfo = async () => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.get(`${API_URL}/medical-info`);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error fetching medical information:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

// Auth APIs
export const signIn = async (credentials) => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.post(`${API_URL}/auth/signin`, credentials);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error signing in:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

export const signUp = async (userInfo) => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.post(`${API_URL}/auth/signup`, userInfo);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error signing up:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

export const logout = async () => {
    try {
        const response = await axios.post(`${API_URL}/auth/logout`);
        return response.data;
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error logging out:', error);
        throw error;
    }
};

// WebSocket connection
export const connectWebSocket = (onMessage) => {
    const socket = new WebSocket(WS_URL);

    socket.onopen = () => {
        console.log('WebSocket connection established');
    };

    socket.onmessage = (event) => {
        onMessage(event.data);
    };

    socket.onerror = (error) => {
        console.error('WebSocket error:', error);
    };

    socket.onclose = () => {
        console.log('WebSocket connection closed');
    };

    return socket;
};

                    <Route path="/events" component={Events} />

The error you're encountering suggests that useHistory is not being exported from react-router-dom in your version. This is likely because useHistory has been replaced with useNavigate in React Router v6. Let's update your code to use the latest version of React Router.

Update SignIn Component

Replace useHistory with useNavigate:

SignIn.js

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom'; // Import useNavigate for navigation
import '@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css';
import '../../../assets/CSS/SignIn.css';
import { signIn } from '../../../api'; // Adjust the import path as needed

const SignIn = () => {
    const [username, setUsername] = useState('');
    const [password, setPassword] = useState('');
    const [message, setMessage] = useState('');
    const navigate = useNavigate(); // useNavigate hook for navigation

    const handleLogin = async (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        try {
            const response = await signIn({ username, password });
            if (response.success) { // Assuming API returns a success field
                setMessage('You are logged in');
                navigate('/events'); // Navigate to Events component
            } else {
                setMessage('Credentials are wrong');
            }
        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Error:', error);
            setMessage('Error logging in');
        }
    };

    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="screen">
                <div className="screen__content">
                    <form className="login" onSubmit={handleLogin}>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-user"></i>
                            <input
                                type="text"
                                className="login__input"
                                placeholder="Username"
                                value={username}
                                onChange={(e) => setUsername(e.target.value)}
                            />
                        </div>
                        <div className="login__field">
                            <i className="login__icon fas fa-lock"></i>
                            <input
                                type="password"
                                className="login__input"
                                placeholder="Password"
                                value={password}
                                onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
                            />
                        </div>
                        <button className="button login__submit" type="submit">
                            <span className="button__text">Sign In</span>
                            <i className="button__icon fas fa-chevron-right"></i>
                        </button>
                    </form>
                    {message && <p>{message}</p>}
                    <div className="social-login">
                        <h3>New user?</h3>
                        <div className="social-icons">
                            <a href="/signup" className="social-login__icon">Sign Up</a>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                    <div className="homepage">
                        <h5><a href="/">Home Page</a></h5>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <div className="screen__background">
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape4"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape3"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape2"></span>
                    <span className="screen__background__shape screen__background__shape1"></span>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
};

export default SignIn;

The issue you're encountering with the sendMessageToAll method not being resolved in WebSocketHandler suggests that either the method doesn't exist in the WebSocketHandler class or you may need to implement it.

Here's a step-by-step guide to resolve this:

  1. Implement sendMessageToAll Method in WebSocketHandler:

    If WebSocketHandler is a class you control, you need to add the sendMessageToAll method. If it's part of a library, you'll need to create a wrapper or an extension of this class to include this functionality.

Example: Implementing sendMessageToAll in Custom WebSocketHandler

First, ensure you have a custom WebSocket handler class where you can add this method:

CustomWebSocketHandler.java

java
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class CustomWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        // Handle received messages if needed
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws IOException {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

    Now, update your service class to use this custom WebSocket handler.

        } catch (JsonProcessingException e) {
            throw new ServicesExceptions("Error serializing person object");
        }

        if (json != null) {
            try {
                webSocketHandler.sendMessageToAll(json);
            } catch (Exception e) {
                throw new RuntimeException(e);
            }
        }

        LogInfo logInfo = new LogInfo(username, password, username, null);
        if (dbLogInfo.findByUsername(logInfo.getUsername()) == null) {
            throw new InvalidCredentialsException("Username does not exist");
        }
        Person person = dbPerson.findByUsername(logInfo.getUsername());
        if (loggedInUsers.containsKey(person.getPersonLogInfo().getUsername()) && loggedInUsers.get(username)) {
            throw new UserAlreadyLoggedInException("User is already logged in");
        }
        return Optional.of(person);
    }

  1. Configure WebSocket in Spring Configuration:

Ensure you have the WebSocket configuration in your Spring application to use the custom WebSocket handler.

WebSocketConfig.java

java
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocket;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketConfigurer;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketHandlerRegistry;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocket
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketConfigurer {

    private final CustomWebSocketHandler customWebSocketHandler;

    public WebSocketConfig(CustomWebSocketHandler customWebSocketHandler) {
        this.customWebSocketHandler = customWebSocketHandler;
    }

    @Override
    public void registerWebSocketHandlers(WebSocketHandlerRegistry registry) {
        registry.addHandler(customWebSocketHandler, "/ws");
    }
}

To set up a WebSocket connection in your Java Spring Boot application, the connection URL is determined by the server's address, port, and the endpoint path you've configured in your WebSocket configuration. Based on the provided information and typical Spring WebSocket setups, your WebSocket connection URL would look something like this:

WebSocket Configuration

Given the following example WebSocket configuration:

WebSocketConfig.java

java
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocket;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketConfigurer;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketHandlerRegistry;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocket
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketConfigurer {

    private final CustomWebSocketHandler customWebSocketHandler;

    public WebSocketConfig(CustomWebSocketHandler customWebSocketHandler) {
        this.customWebSocketHandler = customWebSocketHandler;
    }

    @Override
    public void registerWebSocketHandlers(WebSocketHandlerRegistry registry) {
        registry.addHandler(customWebSocketHandler, "/ws");
    }
}

Here, the WebSocket endpoint is /ws.

WebSocket Connection URL

Since your application runs on localhost with port 55555, the WebSocket connection URL will be:

javascript
const socket = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:55555/ws');

Example JavaScript Client Code

Heres an example of how you might connect to the WebSocket server from a JavaScript client:

client.js

javascript
const socket = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:55555/ws');

socket.onopen = () => {
    console.log('WebSocket connection established');
    // You can send messages to the server like this:
    // socket.send('Hello Server!');
};

socket.onmessage = (event) => {
    console.log('Message from server ', event.data);
};

socket.onerror = (error) => {
    console.error('WebSocket error: ', error);
};

socket.onclose = () => {
    console.log('WebSocket connection closed');
};

Ensure WebSocket Handler

Make sure your CustomWebSocketHandler is implemented correctly to handle WebSocket connections:

CustomWebSocketHandler.java

java
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class CustomWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        // Handle received messages if needed
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws IOException {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

Summary

  1. WebSocket Endpoint: /ws
  2. Connection URL: ws://localhost:55555/ws

Ensure your server is running and listening on the specified port, and the WebSocket handler is registered correctly. The client code provided above will connect to the WebSocket server, handle messages, and manage the connection lifecycle.

The error you are encountering ("Unexpected server response: 500") suggests that there is an issue on the server side. To troubleshoot this, you need to check a few things in your Spring Boot application:

  1. WebSocket Configuration: Ensure that your WebSocket configuration is correct.
  2. WebSocket Endpoint: Make sure the endpoint you are trying to connect to is correct and properly mapped.
  3. Handler Implementation: Check the implementation of your WebSocket handler to ensure it can handle connections.

Heres a checklist and an example of a proper WebSocket setup in a Spring Boot application:

WebSocket Configuration

Ensure you have a configuration class that sets up the WebSocket handler:

WebSocketConfig.java

java
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocket;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketConfigurer;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketHandlerRegistry;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocket
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketConfigurer {

    private final CustomWebSocketHandler customWebSocketHandler;

    public WebSocketConfig(CustomWebSocketHandler customWebSocketHandler) {
        this.customWebSocketHandler = customWebSocketHandler;
    }

    @Override
    public void registerWebSocketHandlers(WebSocketHandlerRegistry registry) {
        registry.addHandler(customWebSocketHandler, "/client-websocket").setAllowedOrigins("*");
    }
}

Your setup includes both ClientWebSocketHandler and a broader WebSocketHandler implementation for handling WebSocket connections. Let's streamline the setup and ensure everything is configured correctly to avoid the 500 error when trying to connect.

WebSocket Configuration

Ensure your WebSocket configuration class is correctly set up to register the endpoints.

WebSocketConfig.java

java
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

WebSocket Handlers

Ensure your custom WebSocket handlers are correctly implemented. Here's a simplified version using only one handler for demonstration:

ClientWebSocketHandler.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        // Handle messages from clients if needed
        for (WebSocketSession webSocketSession : sessions) {
            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

Testing with Postman

Ensure your WebSocket URL in Postman matches the endpoint you've set up. For example, if you're testing the client-websocket endpoint:

  1. Open Postman.
  2. Create a new WebSocket request:
    • URL: ws://localhost:55555/client-websocket
  3. Connect.

If you still encounter issues, ensure there are no server-side errors or stack traces in your Spring Boot application logs that can give more insight into the problem.

Additional Debugging Tips

  1. Check Server Logs: Look for any exceptions or error messages in the Spring Boot console output.
  2. Verify Endpoint: Ensure the WebSocket endpoint is correctly registered and accessible.
  3. Cross-Origin Requests: Ensure that the setAllowedOriginPatterns("*") is correctly allowing connections from your testing tool or frontend.
  4. Spring Security: If you have Spring Security enabled, ensure it's configured to allow WebSocket connections.

By ensuring your WebSocket configuration is correct and the endpoints are properly set up, you should be able to establish a WebSocket connection successfully using Postman or any other WebSocket client.

could it be because only the controller is like in the main module?

It's possible that the issue you're facing could be due to how your application is structured, especially if the WebSocket handlers or configurations are not being properly scanned or initialized. In Spring Boot, components like controllers, handlers, and configurations need to be in packages that are scanned by the Spring Boot application.

Here are some steps to ensure everything is properly configured and scanned:

Step 1: Ensure Package Scanning

Make sure your main application class is in a package that is a parent to all other packages containing your configurations, controllers, and WebSocket handlers.

Main Application Class

Your main application class should look something like this:

BPositiveServerApplication.java

java
package bpos.server;

import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.SpringBootApplication;

@SpringBootApplication
public class BPositiveServerApplication {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(BPositiveServerApplication.class, args);
    }
}

Package Structure

Ensure your package structure is something like this:

bpos.server

 BPositiveServerApplication.java

 service
    Implementation
    Interfaces
    WebSockets
       ClientWebSocketHandler.java
       NotificationService.java
       WebSocketConfig.java

 controller
    YourController.java

 repository
    Interfaces
    YourRepositoryImplementation.java

Step 2: Annotate Components Properly

Ensure that all your components are annotated properly so that Spring can pick them up.

WebSocketConfig.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {
    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

Step 3: Ensure Spring Boot Application Scans the Packages

By default, Spring Boot will scan the package of the main application class and its sub-packages. If your components are not in sub-packages, you can use @ComponentScan to specify the packages to scan.

BPositiveServerApplication.java

java
package bpos.server;

import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.SpringBootApplication;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.ComponentScan;

@SpringBootApplication
@ComponentScan(basePackages = {"bpos.server", "bpos.server.service", "bpos.server.controller"})
public class BPositiveServerApplication {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(BPositiveServerApplication.class, args);
    }
}

Step 2: Verify WebSocket Configuration

Ensure your WebSocket configuration is correctly set up to register the handlers.

WebSocketConfig.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

Step 3: Check for Spring Security Configuration

If you have Spring Security configured, make sure it's not blocking WebSocket connections.

SecurityConfig.java

java
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.security.config.annotation.web.builders.HttpSecurity;
import org.springframework.security.config.annotation.web.configuration.EnableWebSecurity;
import org.springframework.security.config.annotation.web.configuration.WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSecurity
public class SecurityConfig extends WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter {

    @Override
    protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
        http
            .authorizeRequests()
            .antMatchers("/client-websocket/**", "/center-websocket/**", "/admin-websocket/**").permitAll()
            .anyRequest().authenticated()
            .and()
            .csrf().disable()
            .formLogin().disable();
    }
}

Example JavaScript WebSocket Client

javascript
const socket = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:55555/client-websocket');

socket.onopen = () => {
    console.log('WebSocket connection established');
    socket.send('Hello Server!');
};

socket.onmessage = (event) => {
    console.log('Message from server ', event.data);
};

socket.onerror = (error) => {
    console.error('WebSocket error: ', error);
};

socket.onclose = () => {
    console.log('WebSocket connection closed');
};

package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;

@Configuration

    @Override

        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();

ClientWebSocketHandler.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        // Handle messages from clients if needed
        for (WebSocketSession webSocketSession : sessions) {
            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

Step 2: Debugging REST API Endpoints

The 404 error for your REST API endpoints indicates that the server cannot find the requested resource. Ensure that the endpoints are correctly mapped in your Spring Boot application.

Example Controller

Ensure you have a controller that handles the /events endpoint.

EventsController.java

java
package bpos.server.controller;

import bpos.common.model.Event;
import bpos.server.service.EventService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/events")
public class EventsController {

    @Autowired
    private EventService eventService;

    @GetMapping
    public List<Event> getAllEvents() {
        return eventService.findAllEvents();
    }

    @PostMapping("/join")
    public String joinEvent(@RequestBody JoinEventRequest joinEventRequest) {
        return eventService.joinEvent(joinEventRequest.getEventId());
    }
}

class JoinEventRequest {
    private int eventId;

    public int getEventId() {
        return eventId;
    }

    public void setEventId(int eventId) {
        this.eventId = eventId;
    }
}

EventService.java

java
package bpos.server.service;

import bpos.common.model.Event;
import bpos.server.repository.EventRepository;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;

import java.util.List;

@Service
public class EventService {

    @Autowired
    private EventRepository eventRepository;

    public List<Event> findAllEvents() {
        return eventRepository.findAll();
    }

    public String joinEvent(int eventId) {
        // Logic to join the event
        return "Joined event with ID: " + eventId;
    }
}

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

ClientWebSocketHandler.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        // Handle messages from clients if needed
        for (WebSocketSession webSocketSession : sessions) {
            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

package bpos.server.controller;

import bpos.common.model.Event;
import bpos.server.service.EventService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/events")
public class EventsController {

    @Autowired
    private EventService eventService;

    @GetMapping
    public List<Event> getAllEvents() {
        return eventService.findAllEvents();
    }

    @PostMapping("/join")
    public String joinEvent(@RequestBody JoinEventRequest joinEventRequest) {
        return eventService.joinEvent(joinEventRequest.getEventId());
    }
}

class JoinEventRequest {
    private int eventId;

    public int getEventId() {
        return eventId;
    }

    public void setEventId(int eventId) {
        this.eventId = eventId;
    }
}

package bpos.server.service;

import bpos.common.model.Event;

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

Ensure WebSocket Handler is Properly Defined

Ensure the ClientWebSocketHandler is correctly implemented and annotated.

ClientWebSocketHandler.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        // Handle messages from clients if needed
        for (WebSocketSession webSocketSession : sessions) {
            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

WebSocket Configuration

Make sure your WebSocket configuration is properly defined:

WebSocketConfig.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

WebSocket Handlers

ClientWebSocketHandler.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());

            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
            }
        }
    }
}

This issue can occur if there are conflicts or if the WebSocket endpoint registration is not being correctly recognized. Let's review and ensure the proper setup for your WebSocket configuration and handlers.

Ensure Proper Configuration and Separation of WebSocket and REST Endpoints

1. WebSocket Configuration

Ensure your WebSocketConfig is correctly set up and scanned by Spring.

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
    }
}

2. WebSocket Handlers

Ensure your WebSocket handlers are correctly defined and annotated with @Component.

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;

import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;

            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        System.out.println("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {

3. Main Application Class

Ensure the @ComponentScan annotation includes the package where your WebSocket components are located.

java
package bpos.server;

import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;

4. Separate WebSocket and REST Endpoints

Ensure that your WebSocket endpoints are not conflicting with your REST endpoints.

For example, if you have a CenterController with a findOneCenter method, make sure it is not conflicting with your WebSocket endpoint.

java
package bpos.server.controller;

import bpos.common.model.Center;
import bpos.server.service.CenterService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/centers")
public class CenterController {

    @Autowired
    private CenterService centerService;

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public ResponseEntity<Center> findOneCenter(@PathVariable Integer id) {
        Center center = centerService.findById(id);
        if (center != null) {
            return ResponseEntity.ok(center);
        } else {
            return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND).body(null);
        }
    }
}

Summary

  • Ensure that your WebSocket configuration and handlers are correctly defined and separated from your REST endpoints.
  • Make sure the @ComponentScan annotation includes the package where your WebSocket components are located.
  • Test the WebSocket connection using a simple JavaScript client or Postman.
  • Ensure there are no conflicting endpoints between your WebSocket and REST controllers.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the issues and successfully connect to the WebSocket and REST API endpoints. If issues persist, detailed error messages in the logs will provide more specific information.

can u put messages so i know it is there

WebSocket Configuration with Logging

WebSocketConfig.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(WebSocketConfig.class);

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        logger.info("Configuring message broker...");
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        logger.info("Registering STOMP endpoints...");
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        logger.info("STOMP endpoints registered.");
    }
}

WebSocket Handler with Logging

ClientWebSocketHandler.java

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(ClientWebSocketHandler.class);
    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        logger.info("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        logger.info("Received message: " + message.getPayload() + " from session: " + session.getId());
        for (WebSocketSession webSocketSession : sessions) {
            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
                logger.info("Sent message: " + message.getPayload() + " to session: " + webSocketSession.getId());
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        logger.info("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        logger.info("Sending message to all sessions: " + message);
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
                logger.info("Sent message to session: " + session.getId());
            }
        }
    }
}

    "bpos.server",

    "bpos.server.service.WebSockets"

public class BPositiveServerApplication {

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(BPositiveServerApplication.class);

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(BPositiveServerApplication.class, args);
        logger.info("BPositiveServerApplication started successfully.");
    }
}

Verifying WebSocket Connection with JavaScript Client

javascript
const socket = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:55555/client-websocket');

socket.onopen = () => {
    console.log('WebSocket connection established');
    socket.send('Hello Server!');
};

socket.onmessage = (event) => {
    console.log('Message from server: ', event.data);
};

socket.onerror = (error) => {
    console.error('WebSocket error: ', error);
};

socket.onclose = () => {
    console.log('WebSocket connection closed');
};

  1. Open Postman.
  2. Create a new WebSocket request.
  3. Enter the WebSocket URL: ws://localhost:55555/client-websocket.
  4. Connect.

The issue seems to be that your Spring Boot application is trying to map the WebSocket endpoints to your REST controller. This is causing a conflict, as the CenterController is being mistakenly hit when trying to establish a WebSocket connection.

Here are the changes you should make:

  1. Update the CenterController to remove the base path from the @RestController annotation. This will prevent the conflict.

  2. Ensure your WebSocket endpoints are properly configured and not being routed to the REST controllers.

Update CenterController.java

java
package bpos.server;

import bpos.common.model.Center;
import bpos.server.service.Implementation.CenterActorService;
import bpos.server.service.ServicesExceptions;
import bpos.server.service.exceptions.UserNotLoggedInException;
import org.springframework.http.HttpStatus;
import org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

import java.util.Optional;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/centers") // Add this line to set the base URL for this controller
public class CenterController {
    private final CenterActorService service;

    public CenterController(CenterActorService service) {
        this.service = service;
    }

    @GetMapping("/username")
    public ResponseEntity<?> findByUsernameCenter(@RequestParam(value="username", required = true) String username) {
        try {
            Center center = service.findByUsernameCenter(username);
            return new ResponseEntity<>(center, HttpStatus.OK);
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return new ResponseEntity<>("Eroare la procesarea cererii: " + e.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
        }
    }

    @GetMapping("/email")
    public ResponseEntity<?> findByEmailCenter(@RequestParam(value="email", required = true) String email) {
        try {
            Center center = service.findByEmailCenter(email);
            return new ResponseEntity<>(center, HttpStatus.OK);
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return new ResponseEntity<>("Eroare la procesarea cererii: " + e.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
        }
    }

    @GetMapping("/name")
    public ResponseEntity<?> findByNameCenter(@RequestParam(value="name", required = true) String name) {
        try {
            Iterable<Center> centers = service.findByNameCenter(name);
            return new ResponseEntity<>(centers, HttpStatus.OK);
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return new ResponseEntity<>("Eroare la procesarea cererii: " + e.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
        }
    }

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public ResponseEntity<?> findOneCenter(@PathVariable Integer id) {
        try {
            Optional<Center> center = service.findOneCenter(id);
            return center.map(value -> new ResponseEntity<>(value, HttpStatus.OK))
                    .orElseGet(() -> new ResponseEntity<>(HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND));
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return new ResponseEntity<>("Eroare la procesarea cererii: " + e.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
        }
    }

    @GetMapping
    public ResponseEntity<?> findAllCenters() {
        try {
            Iterable<Center> centers = service.findAllCenters();
            return new ResponseEntity<>(centers, HttpStatus.OK);
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return new ResponseEntity<>("Eroare la procesarea cererii: " + e.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
        }
    }

    @PutMapping
    public ResponseEntity<?> updateCenter(@RequestBody Center entity) {
        try {
            Optional<Center> updatedCenter = service.updateCenter(entity);
            if (updatedCenter.isPresent()) {
                return ResponseEntity.ok(updatedCenter.get());
            } else {
                return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR).body("Failed to update center");
            }
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR).body("Internal Server Error");
        }
    }

    @DeleteMapping
    public ResponseEntity<?> deleteCenter(@RequestParam Center entity) {
        try {
            Optional<Center> deletedCenter = service.deleteCenter(entity);
            if (deletedCenter.isPresent()) {
                return ResponseEntity.ok("Center deleted successfully");
            } else {
                return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND).body("Center not found");
            }
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR).body("Internal Server Error");
        }
    }

    @PostMapping
    public ResponseEntity<?> saveCenter(@RequestBody Center entity) {
        try {
            Optional<Center> savedCenter = service.saveCenter(entity);
            if (savedCenter.isPresent()) {
                return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.CREATED).body(savedCenter.get());
            } else {
                return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR).body("Center could not be saved");
            }
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR).body("Internal Server Error");
        }
    }

    @PostMapping("/logout")
    public ResponseEntity<?> logoutCenter(@RequestParam String username) {
        try {
            Center center = service.findByUsernameCenter(username);
            service.logoutCenter(center);
            return new ResponseEntity<>(HttpStatus.OK);
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return new ResponseEntity<>("Eroare la procesarea cererii: " + e.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
        } catch (UserNotLoggedInException e) {
            throw new RuntimeException(e);
        }
    }

    @PostMapping("/login")
    public ResponseEntity<?> loginCenter(@RequestParam String username, @RequestParam String password) {
        try {
            Center center = service.findByUsernameCenter(username);
            Optional<Center> loggedCenter = service.loginCenter(center.getLogInfo());
            if (loggedCenter.isPresent()) {
                return ResponseEntity.ok(loggedCenter.get());
            } else {
                return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.UNAUTHORIZED).body("Invalid credentials");
            }
        } catch (ServicesExceptions e) {
            return ResponseEntity.status(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR).body("Internal Server Error");
        }
    }
}

Ensure WebSocketConfig.java is properly setup

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.config.MessageBrokerRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.EnableWebSocketMessageBroker;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.StompEndpointRegistry;
import org.springframework.web.socket.config.annotation.WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer;

@Configuration
@EnableWebSocketMessageBroker
public class WebSocketConfig implements WebSocketMessageBrokerConfigurer {

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(WebSocketConfig.class);

    @Override
    public void configureMessageBroker(MessageBrokerRegistry config) {
        logger.info("Configuring message broker...");
        config.enableSimpleBroker("/topic");
        config.setApplicationDestinationPrefixes("/app");
    }

    @Override
    public void registerStompEndpoints(StompEndpointRegistry registry) {
        logger.info("Registering STOMP endpoints...");
        registry.addEndpoint("/client-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/center-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        registry.addEndpoint("/admin-websocket").setAllowedOriginPatterns("*").withSockJS();
        logger.info("STOMP endpoints registered.");
    }
}

Verify your WebSocketHandler.java is correctly implemented

java
package bpos.server.service.WebSockets;

import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;
import org.springframework.web.socket.CloseStatus;
import org.springframework.web.socket.TextMessage;
import org.springframework.web.socket.WebSocketSession;
import org.springframework.web.socket.handler.TextWebSocketHandler;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

@Component
public class ClientWebSocketHandler extends TextWebSocketHandler {

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(ClientWebSocketHandler.class);
    private final List<WebSocketSession> sessions = new ArrayList<>();

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionEstablished(WebSocketSession session) throws Exception {
        sessions.add(session);
        logger.info("WebSocket session established: " + session.getId());
    }

    @Override
    public void handleTextMessage(WebSocketSession session, TextMessage message) throws Exception {
        logger.info("Received message: " + message.getPayload() + " from session: " + session.getId());
        for (WebSocketSession webSocketSession : sessions) {
            if (webSocketSession.isOpen()) {
                webSocketSession.sendMessage(message);
                logger.info("Sent message: " + message.getPayload() + " to session: " + webSocketSession.getId());
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void afterConnectionClosed(WebSocketSession session, CloseStatus status) throws Exception {
        sessions.remove(session);
        logger.info("WebSocket session closed: " + session.getId());
    }

    public void sendMessageToAll(String message) throws Exception {
        logger.info("Sending message to all sessions: " + message);
        for (WebSocketSession session : sessions) {
            if (session.isOpen()) {
                session.sendMessage(new TextMessage(message));
                logger.info("Sent message to session: " + session.getId());
            }
        }
    }
}

The error seems to be related to the way your Person class is being deserialized. The JSON response includes a nested structure with a "person" field, which isn't accounted for in your current deserialization logic.

To handle this, you need to either adjust the JSON response to match the Person class directly or update your deserialization logic to handle the nested structure.

Here are two solutions:

Solution 1: Adjust JSON Response to Match Person Class Directly

If possible, modify the server response to return the Person object directly, without the "person" wrapper.

Solution 2: Update Deserialization Logic to Handle Nested Structure

Update your deserialization logic to account for the "person" field in the JSON response.

java
public Person login(String username, String password) {
    String params = URLEncoder.encode("username", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(username, StandardCharsets.UTF_8) +
            "&" +
            URLEncoder.encode("password", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(password, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);

    // Construct the URI with parameters
    String uriWithParams = BASE_URL + "/login?" + params;

    // Construct the HTTP request using the URI with parameters
    HttpRequest request = HttpRequest.newBuilder()
            .uri(URI.create(uriWithParams))
            .POST(HttpRequest.BodyPublishers.noBody())
            .build();

    try {
        HttpResponse<String> response = httpClient.send(request, HttpResponse.BodyHandlers.ofString());
        ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();

        String responseBody = response.body(); // Assuming httpResponse is the response received from the server
        System.out.println(responseBody); // Display the response body

        // Deserialize the JSON response to a Map
        Map<String, Object> map = objectMapper.readValue(responseBody, new TypeReference<Map<String, Object>>() {});
        
        // Extract the "person" object from the map and convert it to a JSON string
        String personJson = objectMapper.writeValueAsString(map.get("person"));
        
        // Deserialize the "person" JSON string to a Person object
        Person person = objectMapper.readValue(personJson, Person.class);

        System.out.println(person); // Display the Person object

        return person; // Return the deserialized Person object
    } catch (Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
    return null;
}

Explanation:

  1. Serialize personLogInfo in the Person class: Ensure that nested classes like LogInfo, PersonalData, etc., have proper getter and setter methods and are serializable by Jackson.

  2. Deserialization Logic: First, deserialize the response body to a Map to handle the nested "person" structure. Then, extract the person JSON object from the map and deserialize it to the Person class.

Ensure Nested Classes Are Serializable

For this to work correctly, ensure that all nested classes (LogInfo, PersonalData, MedicalInfo, Donation, Event, Institution) are properly set up for Jackson serialization/deserialization:

  • Annotate the classes with @JsonIgnoreProperties(ignoreUnknown = true) if they may contain unknown properties.
  • Ensure they have default constructors and getter/setter methods.

For example:

java
import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonIgnoreProperties;
