    // Fields, constructors, getters, and setters
}

@JsonIgnoreProperties(ignoreUnknown = true)
public class PersonalData {
    // Fields, constructors, getters, and setters
}

// Similar annotations for other nested classes

By making these adjustments, you should be able to properly parse the JSON response into the Person object.

Handling Deserialization

With the above setup, your deserialization logic should work as expected. The following is an example to deserialize a nested JSON structure:

java
public Person login(String username, String password) {
    String params = URLEncoder.encode("username", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(username, StandardCharsets.UTF_8) +
            "&" +
            URLEncoder.encode("password", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(password, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);

    String uriWithParams = BASE_URL + "/login?" + params;

    HttpRequest request = HttpRequest.newBuilder()
            .uri(URI.create(uriWithParams))
            .POST(HttpRequest.BodyPublishers.noBody())
            .build();

    try {
        HttpResponse<String> response = httpClient.send(request, HttpResponse.BodyHandlers.ofString());
        ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();

        String responseBody = response.body();
        System.out.println(responseBody);

        // Deserialize the JSON response to a Map
        Map<String, Object> map = objectMapper.readValue(responseBody, new TypeReference<Map<String, Object>>() {});
        
        // Extract the "person" object from the map and convert it to a JSON string
        String personJson = objectMapper.writeValueAsString(map.get("person"));
        
        // Deserialize the "person" JSON string to a Person object
        Person person = objectMapper.readValue(personJson, Person.class);

        System.out.println(person);
        return person;
    } catch (Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
    return null;
}

This should resolve the deserialization issue and correctly parse the nested JSON response.

Here's how you can do it:

  1. Add Duplicate Handling Strategy to build.gradle

    Open the build.gradle file for the BPositiveCommon:BPositiveModel module and modify the jar task to handle duplicates. You can ignore duplicates or include only one of the conflicting files.

    groovy
    jar {
    duplicatesStrategy = DuplicatesStrategy.EXCLUDE
}

    Alternatively, you can configure the processResources task if the issue arises from resource processing:

    groovy
    processResources {
    duplicatesStrategy = DuplicatesStrategy.EXCLUDE
}

    duplicatesStrategy = DuplicatesStrategy.EXCLUDE

    After updating the build.gradle file, rebuild the project:

    sh
    ./gradlew clean build

To handle Java 8 date and time types like LocalDate with Jackson, you need to register the JavaTimeModule from the jackson-datatype-jsr310 module. This module provides support for Java 8 date and time types.

First, you need to ensure that you have the jackson-datatype-jsr310 dependency in your build.gradle file. Add the following line to your dependencies block:

groovy
dependencies {
    implementation 'com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype:jackson-datatype-jsr310'
}

Next, you need to configure your ObjectMapper to use the JavaTimeModule. Here's how you can do it:

Step 1: Add Dependency

Make sure you have the following dependency in your build.gradle file:

groovy
dependencies {
    implementation 'com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype:jackson-datatype-jsr310:2.14.3'
}

Step 2: Configure ObjectMapper

Modify your code to configure the ObjectMapper to register the JavaTimeModule. Here's an example of how to do this:

java
import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper;
import com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.jsr310.JavaTimeModule;
import java.net.URI;
import java.net.URLEncoder;
import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
import java.net.http.HttpClient;
import java.net.http.HttpRequest;
import java.net.http.HttpResponse;

public class LoginService {

    private static final String BASE_URL = "http://your-api-url";
    private HttpClient httpClient = HttpClient.newHttpClient();

    public Person login(String username, String password) {
        String params = URLEncoder.encode("username", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(username, StandardCharsets.UTF_8) +
                "&" +
                URLEncoder.encode("password", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(password, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);

        // Construct URI with parameters
        String uriWithParams = BASE_URL + "/login?" + params;

        // Construct HTTP request using URI with parameters
        HttpRequest request = HttpRequest.newBuilder()
                .uri(URI.create(uriWithParams))
                .POST(HttpRequest.BodyPublishers.noBody())
                .build();

        try {
            HttpResponse<String> response = httpClient.send(request, HttpResponse.BodyHandlers.ofString());
            ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();
            objectMapper.registerModule(new JavaTimeModule());

            String responseBody = response.body(); // Assuming httpResponse is the response received from the server
            System.out.println(responseBody); // Display the response body

            Person person = objectMapper.readValue(responseBody, Person.class);
            System.out.println(person); // Display the Person object
            return person;
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
        return null;
    }
}

Step 3: Ensure Person and PersonalData Classes are Properly Annotated

Make sure that the Person and PersonalData classes are properly set up to be deserialized. You may need to use the @JsonFormat annotation to specify the format of the date if it's not the default ISO format.

For example:

java
import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonFormat;
import java.time.LocalDate;

public class PersonalData {
    private Address address;
    private String phoneNumber;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
    private String cnp;
    private String sex;

    @JsonFormat(shape = JsonFormat.Shape.STRING, pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd")
    private LocalDate birthDate;

    // getters and setters
}

This configuration should resolve the issue you are encountering with parsing LocalDate. By registering the JavaTimeModule, Jackson will be able to handle Java 8 date and time types appropriately.

and for localdatetime

To handle LocalDateTime with Jackson, you can follow a similar approach as for LocalDate. You need to ensure that your ObjectMapper is configured to use the JavaTimeModule, and you can use the @JsonFormat annotation to specify the format of the LocalDateTime.

Heres a step-by-step guide:

Step 1: Ensure the Dependency is Added

Make sure you have the jackson-datatype-jsr310 dependency in your build.gradle file:

groovy
dependencies {
    implementation 'com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype:jackson-datatype-jsr310:2.14.3'
}

Step 2: Register the JavaTimeModule

Configure your ObjectMapper to register the JavaTimeModule. Here is an example of how to do this:

java
import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper;
import com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.jsr310.JavaTimeModule;
import java.net.URI;
import java.net.URLEncoder;
import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
import java.net.http.HttpClient;
import java.net.http.HttpRequest;
import java.net.http.HttpResponse;

public class LoginService {

    private static final String BASE_URL = "http://your-api-url";
    private HttpClient httpClient = HttpClient.newHttpClient();

    public Person login(String username, String password) {
        String params = URLEncoder.encode("username", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(username, StandardCharsets.UTF_8) +
                "&" +
                URLEncoder.encode("password", StandardCharsets.UTF_8) + "=" + URLEncoder.encode(password, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);

        // Construct URI with parameters
        String uriWithParams = BASE_URL + "/login?" + params;

        // Construct HTTP request using URI with parameters
        HttpRequest request = HttpRequest.newBuilder()
                .uri(URI.create(uriWithParams))
                .POST(HttpRequest.BodyPublishers.noBody())
                .build();

        try {
            HttpResponse<String> response = httpClient.send(request, HttpResponse.BodyHandlers.ofString());
            ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();

            System.out.println(responseBody); // Display the response body

            System.out.println(person); // Display the Person object
            return person;
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
        return null;
    }
}

Step 3: Use @JsonFormat for LocalDateTime

Make sure that your Person and other relevant classes are properly annotated to handle LocalDateTime. You can use the @JsonFormat annotation to specify the format for LocalDateTime.

For example:

java
import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonFormat;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;

public class Event {
    private Integer id;
    private String eventName;

    @JsonFormat(shape = JsonFormat.Shape.STRING, pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss")
    private LocalDateTime eventAnnouncementDate;

    @JsonFormat(shape = JsonFormat.Shape.STRING, pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss")
    private LocalDateTime eventStartDate;

    @JsonFormat(shape = JsonFormat.Shape.STRING, pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss")
    private LocalDateTime eventEndDate;

    // Other fields, getters and setters
}

Full Example of the Person and PersonalData Classes

Here is an example of how your Person and PersonalData classes could look:

java
import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonFormat;
import java.time.LocalDate;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class Person extends Entity<Integer> {
    private LogInfo personLogInfo;
    private Integer points;
    private PersonalData personalDate;
    private MedicalInfo medicalInfo; // Se preiau din baza de date la need
    private List<Donation> donations; // Se preiau din baza de date la need
    private List<Event> events;
    private Institution institution;

    public Person() {}

    public Person(LogInfo personLogInfo, Integer points, PersonalData personalDate, MedicalInfo medicalInfo, Institution institution) {
        this.personLogInfo = personLogInfo;
        this.points = points;
        this.personalDate = personalDate;
        this.medicalInfo = medicalInfo;
        this.institution = institution;
        this.donations = new ArrayList<>();
    }

    // Getters and setters...

    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return "Person{" +
                "personLogInfo=" + personLogInfo +
                ", points=" + points +
                ", personalDate=" + personalDate +
                ", medicalInfo=" + medicalInfo +
                ", donations=" + donations +
                ", events=" + events +
                ", institution=" + institution +
                ", id=" + id +
                "} " + super.toString();
    }
}

@JsonIgnoreProperties(ignoreUnknown = true)
public class PersonalData {
    private Address address;
    private String phoneNumber;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
    private String cnp;
    private String sex;

    @JsonFormat(shape = JsonFormat.Shape.STRING, pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd")
    private LocalDate birthDate;

    // Getters and setters...
}

By following these steps, you should be able to correctly parse LocalDateTime in addition to LocalDate with Jackson.
